dialogueHeader.title: SACK-FULL OF NEWES
dialogueHeader.author: unknown
dialogueHeader.contemporaneity: Source text dates from same year as the first printing / original speech event

textBibliography.frontMatter: THE SACK-FULL OF NEWES. LONDON, PRINTED BY ANDREW CLARK, AND ARE TO BE SOLD BY THOMAS PASSENGER AT THE THREE-BIBLES UPON LONDON BRIDGE, 1673. PP. A2R.1 - A5R.12 SAMPLE 1 PP. A7R.14 - A8R.15 SAMPLE 2 PP. A8V.8 - B2R.14 SAMPLE 3 P. B4R.1 - B4R.17 SAMPLE 4

sample.nonSpeech: In the Country of Almaine , in a certain Village, there was on a time a Parson of a Church which preached unto his Parishioners, and thereby shewed them the joys of Heaven and the pains of Hell, and many other things. And as he thus preached in the Pulpit, among the people, there was a Miller which knew well that the Priest had a concubine, and spake so loud that every body did hear him.
sample.dialogue: What foolish Priest,

thou makest much babling in the Pulpit, and all thy wit is not worth a straw: for I have an Asse that is far wiser than thou art, and thou makest here much ado of Heaven and Hell, and I may if I will have both Heaven and Hell at mine own house, winde and weather at mine own will, and as it pleaseth me.
sample.nonSpeech: Wherewith the Priest was greatly displeased, because he disturbed him in his Sermon, and said he would complain thereof to the Bishop.
sample.dialogue: Well,
if thou dost complain, I will abide by that which I have said.
sample.nonSpeech:
But as soon as the Priest had done his Sermon, he went to the Bishop, & complained unto him of all that which the Miller had formerly spoken, whereupon the Bishop incontinently sent
for the Miller, and when the miller came, the Bishop demanded if he could reasonably answer the complaint made against him by the Priest;
sample.dialogue: Yea my Lord
that I can. Well,

thou saidst that thou mightest have thy choice both of heaven and hell at home in thine own house, when it pleaseth thee; and more over thou saidst, thou hadst both wind and weather at thine own pleasure: and also thou saidst, thou hast an Ass that is far wiser than the Parish Priest. If thou canst prove thy saying true, thou shalt go quit without danger. Indeed,

I said, that I had the choice of heaven and hell at mine own house if I would, and so I have, for I have a Mother of mine at home, that is so old that she can neither go nor stand, and I trust as long as I keep her well and do her good, I shall by the grace of God, have heaven at will, and if I do not that I deserve perpetual damnation: and likewise I said, that I had both wind and weather at will, and that is true; for if it be the Lords will that I have good wind and weather, it is my will also and I am very well contented therewith: & if it be his will to send me otherwise, it is my will also, and I am pleased therewith: & whereas I said, that I had an Ass that was wiser than
our Priest, that is most true; for mine Ass sometime when he stumbleth in a hole as she goeth she will beware that she come no more that way, but looketh well before her, and will take heed that she do fall no more therein; but this Priest hath had a Maid this seven years and more, which he lyeth withall, and falleth oft in her hole, and yet he cannot beware of it. And thus I hope I have sufficiently answered to this complaint. Well
thou hast answered, & wisely and therefore go thy ways.
sample.nonSpeech: There was a Fryer in London , which did use to go often to the house of an old woman, and ever when he came to her house, she hid all the meat she had. On a time this Fryer came to her house. (bringing certain company with him) and demanded of the Wife if she had any meat. And she said,
sample.dialogue: Nay. Well
have you not a whetstone? Yea
what will you do with it? Marry
I would make meat thereof.
sample.nonSpeech:
Then she brought a whetstone. He asked her likewise if
she had not a Frying-pan.
sample.dialogue: Yea,
but what the divil will ye do therewith? Marry
you shall see by and by what I will do with it:
sample.nonSpeech: and when he had the pan, he set it on the fire, and put the whetstone therein.
sample.dialogue: Cocks body,
you will burn the pan. No, no,
if you will give me some eggs, it will not burn at all.
sample.nonSpeech: But she would have had the pan from him, when that she saw it was in danger; yet he would not let her, but still urged her to fetch him some eggs, which she did.
sample.dialogue: Tush
here are not enow, go fetch ten or twelve.
sample.nonSpeech: So the good Wife was constrayned to fetch more, for feare lest the Pan should burn; And when he had them, he put them in the pan.
sample.dialogue: Now
if you have no butter, the pan will burn and the eggs too.
sample.nonSpeech: So the good wife being very loth to have her Pan burnt, and her eggs lost, she fetcht him a dish of butter, the which he put into the pan and made good meat thereof, & brougt it to the table, saying
sample.dialogue: Much good may it do you my Masters, now may you say, you have eaten of a buttered Whetstone.

dialogue.comment: AN OLD MAN WITH POOR EYESIGHT HAS A YOUNG WIFE. THE YOUNG WIFE HAS A SERVANT WHO IS ALSO HER LOVER. ONE NIGHT THE WIFE TELLS HER SERVANT TO COME INTO HER AND HER HUSBAND'S BEDROOM AT MIDNIGHT.

sample.nonSpeech: but a little before the time prefixed, she awakned her husband and said thus unto him,
sample.dialogue:
Sir, I will tell you a thing in secret, which your servant was purposed to do; when I am alone, I can never be at quiet for him, but he is always enticeing me to have me at his will, and so at the last to be quiet with him, I consented to meet him in the garden, but for mine honesties sake I will not. Wherefore I pray you put on my cloathes and go meet him: so when he comes to you, beat him well, and chide him, for I know well he will not strike you,
because you are his Master, and then he may amend himself & prove a good servant: THE HUSBAND GOES OUT TO THE GARDEN. THE SERVANT COMES TO THE WIFE AND SHE TELLS HIM WHAT SHE HAS SAID TO HER HUSBAND. AFTER A WHILE THE SERVANT GOES TO THE GARDEN WHERE HE MEETS HIS MASTER.
sample.nonSpeech: as though he knew not it was his Master, & said unto him,
sample.dialogue: Nay you whore, I did this but only to prove thee, whether thou wouldest be false to my good Master, and not that I would do such a vile thing with thee.
sample.nonSpeech: Whereupon he fell upon his Master, giving him many sore stripes, and beating him most cruelly, still calling him nothing but,
sample.dialogue: Out you Whore, will you offer this abuse to my good Master? Alas,
good John I am thy Master, strike me no more, I pray thee. Nay Whore
I know who thou art well enough
sample.nonSpeech: and so he struck him again, beating him most grievously.
sample.dialogue: Good John
feel I have a beard.
sample.nonSpeech:
Then the servant felt (knowing well who it was) who presently kneeled down, and
cryed his Master mercy.
sample.dialogue: Now thanks be to God,
I have as good a servant of thee as a man can have, and I have as good a wife as the world affords.
sample.nonSpeech: Afterwards the Master went to bed, and his servant also. When the old man came to bed to his Wife; she demanded of him how he sped. He answered and said,
sample.dialogue: By my troth Wife, I have the trustiest servant in the World, and as faithful a Wife; for my servant came thither with a great staff, and did beat me right sore, thinking it had been you; wherefore I was well pleased therewith.
TWO YOUNG PLOUGHMEN HAVE BEEN IN THE CHURCH. Lob I pray thee what was that the Priest went so whinging whanging withal? Why Dob
dost thou not know? It is Frankincense. Is it Frankincense? I am sure it stunk as if the devil had been in the Church.
sample.nonSpeech: There were once too men that were both masterless and moneyless, & one said to the other,
sample.dialogue: What remedy canst thou now find out that we may either get some meat or money? By my troth
I do know a very fine shift,
sample.nonSpeech: (& being very early in the morning, they espyed a man coming with Hogs)
sample.dialogue: Lo yonder cometh a man with Hogs, and I will tell him that they be sheep, & I will cause him to lay a wager with me, whether they be Sheep or hogs: & I will cause the matter to be judged by the next man that cometh, but then thou must go another way & meet with us; when we demand of thee whether they be sheep or hogs, thou must say that they be sheep.
sample.nonSpeech: Then they separated themselves the one from the other, and the one went to meet the man that had the Swine, bidding him good morrow; the man doing the like to him again. Then he said to the old man
sample.dialogue: Father, where had you your fair sheep; What sheep
These sheep that you drive before you: Why
they are Swine. What
will you make me a fool? think you I know not sheep from Swine? Marry

I will lay one of my Swine against what thou wilt, that
they be no Sheep. I hold thee my coat against one of thy sheep,
I am content,
by whom shall we be tryed? By the next man that meets us. Content,
sample.nonSpeech: said the old man. And then they perceived the man coming being the fellow of the young man. And when he came to them, the old man requested him to tel them what beasts those were?
sample.dialogue: Why
they be sheep, do you not know sheep? I told him so,
but he would not believe me, & so I laid my coat upon a Wager that they were sheep, & he laid one of his sheep against my Coat that they were Swine: and I won it, have I not? Yea
but God help me, I bought them for Swine,

dialogue.comment: A BOY FROM THE NORTH IS ASKED TO FETCH THE SALAD (SALLET) WHICH HE HAS NEVER HEARD OF. HE FINDS A SALLET (A HELMET).

sample.dialogue: What will my Master do with this in a platter?
sample.nonSpeech: So down he took it, and put it into a Platter and put Dil and Vinegar unto it, and brought it to the table.
sample.dialogue: Why thou knave
I had thee bring the herbs, which we call a Sallet. Now by my Sires sale Master
I did never see such in my Country.

dialogue.comment: A MAN ASKS A BOY TO FETCH HIM SOME COLEWORTS AND SET THEM OVER THE FIRE IN HIS CHAMBER: THE BOY DOES NOT KNOW WHAT A COLEWORT IS AND THINKS THE MAN MEANS COAL. THE BOY FETCHES THE COAL AND PUTS IT ON THE FIRE.

sample.nonSpeech:
he asked him for his Coleworts which he bad him
make ready.
sample.dialogue: Marry sir,
they be almost enough for they have lien rosting in the fire almost this hour. Where are they,
In your chamber sir,
sample.nonSpeech: qd. the boy. So he went into his chamber and there he saw a great fire, and then he asked the boy again where the coleworts were.
sample.dialogue: Why Master

I understood you that you bad me fetch coales and hang them over the fire in the basket, and if I should have done so the basket would have burned: wherefore I took the basket and powred the coals on the fire. O whorson
I bad thee to fetch some coleworts and hang them in a kettle over the fire:

sample.nonSpeech: In the countrey dwelt a Gentlewoman who had a French man dwelling with her, and he did ever use to go to Church with her, and upon a time he and his Mistresse were going to Church and she bad him pull the doore after him and follow her to the Church, and so he took the doore betweene his armes, and lifted it from the hooks, and followed his Mistresse with it: But when she looked behinde her and saw him bring the doore upon his back,
sample.dialogue: Why thou foolish knave,
what wilt thou do with the door? Mary Mistresse,
you bad me pull the doore after me. Why whorson
I did command thee that thou shouldest make fast the doore after thee, & not to bring it upon thy back after me.
